formalText: The last time they met the clinician gave him two pieces of advice.
He found one of two pieces of advice very helpful.
The other was that the clinician suggested that he  is not able to  accept things as not ideal, but also good or evil to do that in general.
He is feeling that Tanya's feeling are volatile or that they're just as volatile as he always is.
His wife Tanya has good moods now, which is good and there are good days, but he feels there are relatively small setbacks.

He can't think of an example off hand of what is a larger impact on Tanya than he would if she were healthier. He says healthier is a relative term that he does not know what it means and then what they had in previous times of their life.
Tanya and him were doing couples counseling but they stopped going to see him.

They had to explain things with Waze (the doctor) and he said that the doctor would respond and he would explain for about four or five times and almost the same way this sort of response, which is how the the patient clearly not feel about the situation.
The patient's wife has been trying to fluctuate her mood after poor mental health months ago, and someone told the patient to log her mood day to day.
